26.95.text:
It's certainly a privilege and
an honor to be here tonight

31.68.text: to meet with all of you.

34.91.text:
And I think my role in
being here tonight is

37.09.text:
to encourage you as we journey
together to fight for life

45.95.text:
It's a real privilege to
speak to a friendly crowd

50.01.text:
because I speak so much to
an anti-life parliament.

54.50.text:
And I look around this room
and I see so many people

57.71.text: who are contributing to the pro-life cause

60.74.text:
here in Queensland which
is actually my home state,

63.23.text: so very close to my heart.

65.88.text:
And I want to commend everyone's
commitment here tonight

69.00.text:
to fight against Pyne's
abortion laws here in Queensland.

74.62.text:
I believe that we are,
in our part of the world,

78.49.text: at a very critical point in our history.

81.68.text: It's a time when we must work together,

85.06.text:
putting aside our differences
which always arise

88.67.text:
when we're working with
people, let's be honest,

91.32.text: when we work together for the common good.

95.88.text:
So tonight, I was given
the topic of talking about

98.46.text:
the highs and the lows
and everything in between

101.16.text:
of campaigning against
abortion in Victoria.

105.40.text:
And I think the main message
I want to convey tonight is

109.80.text:
what you can learn from
the Victorian experience.

114.07.text: We are a cautionary tale for Queensland.

118.57.text:
It is so hard to turn
the tide on abortion laws

126.18.text: We are now stuck in Victoria

128.21.text: with the worst abortion laws imaginable.

135.35.text: We regularly have babies being born alive

137.77.text:
as a result of abortion
who have no right to life.

147.45.text: any clinic where an abortion is performed

149.74.text:
including a GP clinic
where RU-486 is dispensed

158.18.text:
Holistic care for women
is a foreign concept

161.75.text: to many in our medical profession.

There is little recognition
of the concept of hospice

168.67.text:
in the womb and we
completely dismiss babies

176.91.text:
This is a really hard
environment for people like us

181.13.text: to work in because I am pro-life

187.93.text: And if I had my way,

189.10.text:
there would be no abortions
performed in Victoria

195.86.text:
And I think I need to be
really clear on this point

199.07.text:
because as a politician, I

203.14.text:
and go for what is
winnable and achievable.

207.16.text:
And once laws are passed
and go unchallenged

211.23.text:
for years and years and years,
eight years in our case,

215.38.text: it's a rough road to turn them back.

219.56.text:
So I chose to go after
late-term abortion for my bill

224.21.text:
because Galaxy Polling
showed us that a majority

226.61.text:
of Victorians were against
late-term abortion.

229.99.text:
Now I see here on the screen

237.84.text:
So that's even quite a

240.33.text:
Once you have laws, like
we have in Victoria,

243.73.text: the whole society starts to erode.

249.11.text: But, it was a tough call,

252.06.text: but that's what I started to go after.

253.67.text:
So in 2015, I introduced
the Infant Viability Bill.

259.11.text: This bill aimed to protect babies

261.67.text:
of viable gestational
age from termination.

266.93.text: I can count literally on one hand

270.19.text:
the number of people who
share similar values to mine

276.62.text:
And those of us who believe
in Judeo-Christian values

280.12.text: are truly in the lion's den.

283.10.text: We get trolled on the internet.

285.86.text:
Even getting Facebook messages
while we're in the Chamber

288.25.text:
from people in the gallery
telling us that we're idiots.

294.51.text:
We're verbally attacked
in Parliament House.

301.26.text:
And we face constant attempts
to have our voices silenced.

307.38.text:
I was offered bribes to
take my bill off the table

310.60.text: and not bring it to debate.

312.74.text: I could've lived a very comfortable life,

315.52.text: but now is not the time to be silent.

318.76.text: Now is not the time to take bribes.

322.21.text:
The bill made people nervous
and that's a good thing

326.34.text: because MPs in Victoria were uncomfortable

329.05.text:
with having to stand up
and admit to assenting

333.12.text: to the destruction of viable babies.

337.26.text:
They were uncomfortable, and
so they should have been,

340.72.text:
with having to stand up
and admit to denying women

343.37.text:
the opportunity to be
cared for in a holistic way.

348.59.text:
Imagine this, the socialist
left, as I often refer to them,

353.25.text:
is actually denying mothers
in Victoria from counselling

357.03.text:
and support around difficult
or unexpected pregnancies.

361.49.text:
And they simply don't like
being called out on this.

366.66.text:
I sought to bring out the
elements of the abortion law

369.68.text: which they particularly wished to hide

373.12.text:
and it embarrassed them
because their usual arguments

381.38.text:
So the Infant Viability Bill
was the first piece of pro-life

385.28.text:
legislation seen in Victoria
since the Crime's Act

388.80.text: made abortion a criminal offense in 1958.

393.60.text:
We then had our awful
abortion laws come in in 2008.

398.63.text: My bill had three sections, very briefly.

401.99.text:
First section, I introduced
a concept of holistic care

405.49.text:
for mother and baby from
24 weeks' gestation.

408.59.text:
Now, I don't think we
should have to introduce

411.28.text: the concept of holistic care for women,

414.14.text: but in Victoria, we absolutely do

416.99.text:
because it is much more
accepted to have an abortion

420.41.text: than to carry your baby to term,

424.93.text: for want of a better word.

427.58.text:
And I want to just emphasis
half of our late-term

434.41.text: So mothers that feel unable to cope

437.85.text:
for reasons such as homelessness
or they feel suicidal

444.28.text: and we're not giving these women any hope,

446.40.text: we're just taking their baby away

448.20.text: and expecting them to then cope.

452.04.text:
The second section of my
bill sought to protect

455.66.text:
the number of babies that
are born alive in Victoria.

459.82.text:
It would have protected
those babies, for example,

464.15.text: who may not survive long outside the womb,

466.80.text:
but provide them with
appropriate palliative care

470.25.text: as opposed to the death sentence

472.40.text: which they so often get at the moment.

476.78.text:
I tried to take a real
life-affirming approach to the bill

482.74.text:
so even if a baby, if this
section had been passed,

485.74.text:
had been intended for
death through abortion,

489.60.text:
they would have had to be
cared for appropriately.

495.21.text: They're left on shelves to die.

497.40.text:
They're put in buckets,
literally, in Victoria.

501.94.text:
And unfortunately, women
from all over Australia

504.42.text:
are coming to Victoria
for their abortions.

506.91.text: And I was in New Zealand recently

510.18.text:
they put their women on a plane
and send them to Melbourne

512.84.text: for their late-term abortions as well.

518.76.text:
And then section three, the
third section of my bill,

522.34.text:
would have introduced the
definition of late-term abortion

525.18.text:
as intentionally causing
the death of a child

527.30.text:
from 24 weeks' gestation and
make it illegal to do so.

533.36.text: I felt that this was a necessary step,

536.65.text:
but it was defeated,
overwhelmingly defeated.

548.31.text:
Three from the ALP, three
from the Liberal Party,

552.00.text:
two Shooters and Fishers,
two National Party members,

561.10.text: It's pretty light on, isn't it?

two people decided they
couldn't make a decision,

568.97.text:
they promised to vote for

582.01.text:
And clearly, they are
forgetting that pro-lifers vote.

589.56.text:
"My body - my choice" is the
argument most people used

596.69.text:
However, to me, "my body - my
choice" also means "my problem".

601.84.text:
Women are being actively
blamed for pregnancy.

606.29.text: And I'd like to know what happened to

608.34.text: "it takes a village to raise a child"?

614.47.text:
And what happened to valuing
the role of the father?

619.15.text: And what happened to valuing motherhood?

624.13.text: How did we get to this point?

626.49.text:
And some of this feels
like a rhetorical question,

628.53.text: but I think we need to ask them.

631.03.text: How did we find ourselves in a society

633.41.text:
which prefers death
over providing support,

637.75.text: genuine and practical support to women?

642.72.text: And how did we find ourselves in a society

645.00.text: which prefers death over giving respect,

648.10.text:
genuine respect to
mothers and to motherhood?

653.11.text: And how did we find ourselves in a society

660.30.text: because children are viewed as problematic

672.94.text: that their lives mean so little

675.85.text:
that a pregnancy is seen
as an inconvenience,

679.32.text: a disruption of a lifestyle and is wrong?

684.91.text: I truly believe that abortion arises

687.02.text: out of a lack of choice.

689.10.text: It is not the embodiment of choice.

692.51.text: And I don't know about you,

693.64.text: but when I hear the word abortion,

696.52.text:
I think of things like coercion,
vulnerability, betrayal.

703.76.text: I feel sad, my heart aches.

707.61.text:
I remember the two children I
have waiting for me in heaven

714.41.text:
I don't feel judgmental or

719.90.text:
I just simply remember what
it feels like to be a woman

723.90.text: who is pregnant and feeling vulnerable.

734.53.text: And quite simply, it kills children.

740.43.text:
We must work together toward
systematically, methodically

746.88.text:
and deliberately eliminating

I'm a great fan of some of

764.44.text:
especially women who are poor,

She describes that by then
demanding for women the right

779.34.text:
by saying essentially that women

783.91.text:
we have ignored the argument

787.01.text:

791.14.text:
in our society today because

795.73.text: that abortion solves nothing and we mourn

the loss of thousands of

We must focus on promoting
and supporting the human

811.07.text:
flourishing of mothers, of

816.58.text:
and to take a life-affirming

And this is what my

because it focused on

it was a small but it

And what we must do now
is maintain our rage

And we must look forward
to a day where fatherhood

850.09.text:
where motherhood is
respected and supported

854.21.text: and where every child is cherished.

869.10.text:
So tonight I think that we can
focus on some real positives.

874.50.text:
We can focus on the positive
of uniting together,

877.62.text: to take a stand against the injustice

882.77.text:
it's an industry which makes

And it's an industry in

920.83.text:
was started in 2012 in

The fight for life needs

It cannot be forgotten

I believe everyone has a

and particularly women

And the reality is if

Remember, 11 people out

1013.92.text:
So we need MPs in both

I want to thank my DLP colleagues

1026.20.text: but I believe we punch above our weight.

and I would describe

which gives the lobbying

We need them all, and we

The ability to get our message

1188.72.text: I believe that the campaign for my bill

1191.33.text:
brought out the best

1194.47.text:
It united the MPs, the lobbyists

1201.05.text:
And I think the campaign here
to oppose the legislation

1204.03.text:
in Queensland will be
doing the same thing,

1207.17.text: bringing out the best in all of us.

1210.08.text: With all groups sitting together to plan,

1213.37.text: to plot the course with a common goal.

1219.11.text: this is a marathon, it's not a sprint.

1224.74.text:
And reflecting on this
always reminds me of

1227.24.text:
William Wilberforce who's
already been quoted tonight.

1232.57.text: William Wilberforce fought to end slavery.

1249.98.text: to achieve his aim of abolishing slavery,

1253.06.text:
but he continued with
a dogged determination

1256.25.text: that you see in so few MPs today.

1260.70.text: And I love reflecting on his example

1263.78.text: because we now look back at slavery

1266.16.text:
and we are appalled at the
treatment slaves received

1270.84.text: and we're horrified at the very idea

1273.31.text:
that one person could
own another, aren't we?

1279.21.text: I pray that we look back at this era

1282.34.text: appalled at the babies we killed,

1286.14.text:
horrified that we would enslave
women in human trafficking,

1290.64.text:
embarrassed that we would
ever consider deliberately

1297.68.text:
dismayed that we allowed
a generation of children

1300.55.text: to be deprived of a biological identity

1303.43.text: through forced adoptions to gay couples,

1306.54.text:
and in absolute disbelief
that we ever thought

1310.03.text: that embryos should be used for research.

1314.53.text:
And I pray that when we
look back we can say this,

1318.62.text: "When it counted, I did not run.

1322.01.text:
"I did my best and I stood
up for what I knew was right.

1335.71.text:
and I played a role in
caring for children."

1340.56.text:
I just want to encourage
everyone here tonight

1342.72.text:
that even if your
contribution seems small,

1345.83.text:
that we should never
underestimate what you do.

1350.13.text:
Ecclesiastes 9:10 if you don't
mind me quoting the Bible

1353.69.text: says, "Whatever your hand finds to do,

1356.70.text: do it with all your might,

1359.37.text:
for in the realm of the
dead where you are going,

1361.70.text: there is neither working nor planning

1367.68.text: This is something I reflect on often.

1370.37.text: Whatever your hand finds to do,

1372.95.text: do that with all of your might.

1376.75.text:
Everyone in this room has
something that they can be doing

1380.65.text:
and most probably are doing

1385.42.text: I'm going to give you some examples.

1388.07.text:
Maybe you knit tiny booties
and tiny hats for women

1391.53.text:
who have a lost a child
through miscarriage.

1394.80.text: If so, one such set of booties and hats

1398.05.text:
found its way to me when
I lost my third child.

1402.94.text: I keep it in my desk drawer at work

1405.31.text: as a reminder of why I do what I do.

1409.52.text:
You never know from the
little things you do

1417.76.text:
Maybe you were at the 2013 March
for the Babies in Victoria.

1423.36.text: That was a particularly violent rally.

1427.22.text:
I was there on my own
because I couldn't get anyone

1429.72.text: from my church to go with me.

1432.26.text: And people ran through the crowd.

1440.99.text:
They actually punched the
keynote speaker and Bernie Finn.

1444.85.text:
And there was one woman in
particular that I remember.

1451.55.text: She had made a homemade sign to take.

1453.89.text: It had been ripped out of her hand.

1456.86.text: and I was trying to help her patch it up.

1459.61.text: And it was at that point that I decided

1463.43.text: someone needed to stand up for this crowd

1466.62.text: and that I would be an MP.

1469.55.text: You never know who you might inspire.

1473.61.text:
Maybe you pray every morning
and every night for a change.

1477.88.text:
If so, you imbue people
with strength to continue

1481.71.text:
to devote their energy beyond
their physical limitations.

1486.80.text:
Maybe you volunteer your
time at the church playgroup,

1490.63.text: contributing to the lives of children

1492.61.text: and providing valued support for parents.

1497.14.text:
Maybe you have skills that you
simply have not realized yet

1501.33.text: or skills that you're not yet using.

1506.22.text:
Whatever your hand finds
to do, big or small,

1511.14.text: do that with all of your might.

1518.54.text:
"Our lives begin to end
the day we are silent

1525.76.text:
Many of you in this room
have not been silent,

1529.14.text:
but maybe you're discouraged
with slow progress

1531.92.text:
and maybe you're
evaluating your next step.

1534.82.text:
I'm here to encourage you and
to thank you for not being

1538.44.text:
silent about the things that
matter because quite simply,

1543.30.text: we are called to action and we must act.

1548.18.text: We simply cannot be passive bystanders

1551.42.text:
when it comes to the
injustice of abortion.

1561.46.text: And let us not ever be silent.
